Het eindcijfer met het tentamenbriefje voor de Research Workshop wordt gegeven aan het einde van blok 4.
Thema: Reizigers in tijd en ruimte: egodocumenten 1600-1940

De overtuiging dat mensen zelf vorm kunnen geven aan hun persoon en aan de samenleving waarin zij leven, won veld in de 18e eeuw. Mensen konden daarbij leren van voorbeelden en adviezen. In toenemende mate kon men zich daarover informeren in boeken, variërend van (auto)biografieën tot etiquetteboeken, opvoedkundige adviesboeken en, later, romans. Ook de confrontatie met andere volkeren leidde tot een duidelijker definitie van het eigene. Daarover kon wie niet zelf op reis ging geïnformeerd worden door reisverslagen, een steeds populairder genre. Omgekeerd werden Nederlanders en het Nederlandse volk bekeken door buitenlandse ogen. Dat beeld werd eveneens vastgelegd in reisverslagen en reisgidsen, waarvan er steeds meer verschenen dankzij de opkomst van het moderne toerisme. Dezelfde ontwikkelingen deden zich voor in andere Europese landen. De late 18e eeuw was hierbij een cruciale periode met ook de opkomst van de moderne pedagogie en psychologie, en de groeiende populariteit van vormende kinderliteratuur en adviesboeken. Het is de periode waarin een modern toekomstgericht lineair tijdsbesef ontstond en het daarmee verbonden idee dat de geschiedenis onomkeerbaar is, dat het utopisch denken sterk stimuleerde en waarin de gedachte van een maakbare samenleving werd ontwikkeld. Op grond van diverse bronnen - egodocumenten, adviesboeken, biografieën, reisverslagen en utopieën - zal getracht worden greep te krijgen op deze door historici nog nauwelijks in kaart gebrachte ontwikkeling.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81155,2018,Religion, Culture and Global Encounters",Engels,"Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['HLE van der Linden', 'prof.dr. D Douwes']",,"Inhoud

In this course we look at how religion is variously defined in relation to its content and performance as well as to the ways in which religion is organized and impacts on society. Believers rather than believes are central in our approach, religion being considered to be part of particular historical and cultural contexts and wider global political-economic networks that influence religious life. Globalization constitutes the general context of course and responses to globalization on the local and national level are central to our approach.
With the advent of the disciplines of the history of religion and the comparative study of religion in the second half of the 19th
column2: century studying ‘religion’ developed into a secular approach to belief and pious practice. Historically, ‘religion’ referred mainly to institutional and scriptural versions of religions, such as in Judaism, Christianity and Islam. Today a wide variety of ‘divine’ or ‘sacred’ human activities are acknowledged as being ‘ spiritual’&nbsp
column4: ‘religious’, including New Age, Rasta and, even, Wellness.

column1: In the lectures Christianity and Islam figure prominently, representing the two largest and most wide-spread religious traditions on the globe, but due attention will be paid to other traditions.
column2: Moreover, for their assignments and final paper students select a specific religious tradition such as&nbsp
column4: Christianity, Islam, Hinduism, Buddhism, or East Asian or African religions. Of course, when making their topic of choice students have to take in to regard the availability and accessibility of both primary and secondary sources.

column1: In this course various approaches are combined and used to investigate developments within the three following fields that are closely connected with various aspects of
- Religion and colonization (missionaries, colonial policies, local responses, postcolonial developments)
- Religion, migration and citizenship (diaspora’s, transnational communities, debates on (national) identities, including issues of gender)
- Living religion (religion as lifestyle, rituals and beliefs ordering daily life and -possibly- the hereafter)
Note that there is to be an even distribution of students for each of the three themes above.

Students acquire knowledge of the various concepts and definitions of religion and of the changing nature of religion and religious organisation and how these change over time within a global perspective. They acquire the skills to analyse specific cases of social and cultural developments in modern history in which religion is or appears to be a key element as well as the skills to present their findings in a scholarly final paper.

Since the turn of the millennium the democratisation of information- and communication technologies and the proliferation of social media have significantly changed our social interactions and social structures, economies and businesses. This course analyses the digitalisation of everyday life by using case studies of large new media organisations - Wikipedia, Google, Facebook, Youtube and Uber, etc. - structured around themes such as privacy, knowledge, big data, the creative commons and the sharing economy.
It addresses these cases and themes from the perspective of Political Economy and Science &amp
column2: Technology Studies, two very influential critical traditions within the field of New Media Studies. From a political economic perspective we will map, analyse and critically discuss both the organisational ecologies and business models of some of the largest new media organisations. From the perspective of Science &amp
column3: Technology Studies, we will map, analyse and critically discuss the social practices that have shaped, and continue to shape, the interfaces, platforms and applications – and vice versa. In this way, we can pick out and unpick some of today’s most ubiquitous new media organisations, while conceiving them as being part of a larger ‘online ecosystem embedded in a larger socio-cultural and political economic context where [they are] inevitably molded by historical circumstances’, as Jose Van Dijck puts it in The Culture of Connectivity (2013).

column1: This course is structured as a research seminar. This entails that students are required to study the course materials on each case and topic before each session, conduct their own desk- and field research and actively contribute to, and direct, the group discussions.</body>
<body>After this course, students will be able to:
<li>Describe and explain the various histories of the social media platforms and applications under discussion
<li>Understand the basic tenets of the political economic and STS perspectives on Social Media
<li>Critically evaluate the organizational ecologies and business models of the social media platforms and applications under discussion
<li>Critically evaluate the ways in which social practices and social media interfaces are co-constituted
• Formulate a personal standpoint concerning the debates about the ‘effects’ of social media in domains such as privacy, creativity, copyright, distraction, sharing and sociability.
• Write and present a conference research paper.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81159,2018,Representing War in Popular Historical Culture,Engels,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['dr. SM Hogervorst', 'prof.dr. CR Ribbens']",,"Inhoud

World War II until today is an important reference point in popular historical culture, both in the Netherlands and elsewhere. Other large-scale conflicts, such as the First World War, the Cold War and the recent War in the Middle East, are as well appealing historical experiences which have an impact on the collective memory. But the way wars are represented and collectively remembered is anything but immutable and unambiguous. The ways in which wars of the past were brought to the fore (usually outside of academia) during the 20th and 21st centuries for a variety of audiences are quite diverse: ranging from museum exhibitions to comics and novels, and from films and musicals to games and new media. In this course the focus is on the question in what kind of historical representations of war all these elements have resulted, and what meanings are assigned to it? What are the expectations of both producers and consumers regarding different ways of presenting this past, and which views exist on understanding and – in as far as possible - 'experiencing' past wars. The emphasis will be on war representations in the popular historical culture of the Western world and comics in particular.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 25.

The aim of the course is to gain knowledge and understanding of the ways in which war from the early 20th century to the beginning of the 21st century is represented and framed in popular historical culture. Students learn in what ways media, comics in particular, and other forms of historical presentation reflect memories and visions of various large-scale conflicts and how developments in these representations relate to historical interpretations.

<body>Research design refers to a series of interrelated decisions about the kinds of questions that can be answered empirically and how to do so. It covers theoretical and social justifications for asking those questions, considerations on how data should be sampled, collected and analyzed, as well as how (certain kinds of) inferences can be drawn. In this way, the course helps students improve their research design skills and prepares them for developing their own research proposals. Core seminar discussions include: the relationship between theory and research
column2: alternative methodological approaches and styles/traditions of research within the social sciences, as well as the pros and cons of combining methods
column4: and research ethics. Practical constraints that affect research decisions will also be taken into account.

column1: This is an intermediary level course, meant as a review and refresher on research design before students move on to more advanced and specialized courses. Students should come into the course&nbsp

<body>This course sharpens students’ understanding of the different decisions involved in the design of empirical research, as well as the implications of these decisions. It pays special attention to the formulation of (social) scientifically valuable research questions, the selection of and analytical engagement with relevant literature, key methodological possibilities and associated ethical considerations. This will not only strengthen students’ abilities to design a research project of their own, but also give them additional competence (and confidence) to justify their decisions as researchers.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/84094,2018,Research Methodology,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. ES Marti', 'dr. GAJM Berens', 'dr. SP Kennedy']",,"Inhoud

This course will provide students with an understanding on the basics of qualitative and quantitative research methods, as well as the skills to design, conduct and analyze a research study. The overall aim of the course is to provide students with insights and skills to make informed choices regarding the research design to be used for their MSc thesis. The course is structured to coincide with work on the master thesis.

The course will consist of two parts, one (in November-December) devoted to methodological principles, and the other (in March-April) to workshops covering the application of different methods for data collection and analysis. The following topics will be discussed in the two parts.

In the first part of the course, which takes place in November and December, we provide an introduction to methodological principles underlying both qualitative and quantitative methods. In the first week, we will cover the nature of qualitative and quantitative research, types of research objectives, types of research design, criteria for research quality, and types of data collection methods.

The first week will also include a ‘meet the coaches’ session during which faculty members briefly present their areas of expertise and interest, after which students can have an informal chat with potential thesis coaches to determine areas of potential mutual interest.

The second part of the course, which takes place in March and April, consists of a series of workshops on specific qualitative and quantitative data collection and analysis methods, such as interviews, experiments, surveys, case studies, coding, and regression analysis. Students are expected to follow at least three of these workshops, depending on the methods they will be using in their thesis research.

Classes in the first part will consist of lectures, group discussions, student presentations, and in-class exercises in which an application of a particular research method is reviewed. The workshops will be hands-on and applied to the students’ own research projects.

For the first part of the course, students will be graded on a paper that consists of a draft methods section for the student’s master thesis, in which the student describes two possible methods to answer a research question (s)he is interested in (i.e. a ‘plan A’ and a ‘plan B’). The paper will consist of 2-3 pages, single spaced, excluding references. The paper will be due on Saturday, December 22nd&nbsp
At the end of this course, students should be able to:
Understand the process of qualitative and quantitative research, including research questions, design, data collection, analysis and reporting
Describe the qualities and limitations of various approaches to qualitative and quantitative research, including the strengths and drawbacks of different data sources
Reflect on the considerations inherent in designing and undertaking a research study, in the context of their own thesis.

During this first module participants will take part in a range of interactive masterclasses and workshops to not only get to know each other, but also to come to understand and appreciate that this programme is truly academic in nature. After completion of this module, participants will have come to understand a wide range of key concepts and approaches underlying the research methodologies covered in this programme. In particular, participants will have developed the academic mindset and the attitude that is required to study, evaluate, discuss, design, execute, and present academic research. In this module it will be shown how rigorous research is fundamental to effectively address today’s complex problems at the intersection of customs, logistics, and compliance.

• differentiate and explain theory-oriented research and design science research

More in general, after this module participants will have improved their abilities and attitude to process and discuss the literature and research findings that will be covered in future modules.

This course will be your kick-off into the world of research and will cover the fundamental principles of science, research designs, measurement, sampling, and ethics. This basic material will lay the groundwork for the more technical stuff that we will cover in subsequent courses. We will use examples from a range of social and behavioural science disciplines, including: sociology, political sciences, and psychology.

This course makes use of a blended learning format, which describes the growing phenomenon by which students learn at least in part by way of digital or online media. Here, the online component is the video lectures. Video lectures replace traditional in-class lectures and are provided by UvA through an existing Massive Open Online Course (MOOC) entitled Quantitative Methods.¹ At EUC, weekly offline tutorials are held in which small groups discuss the course material with their tutor, and complete exercises aimed at understanding the practical side of the conceptual material presented in the video lectures. This blended learning format allows you significantly more control over the pace and style in which you learn the course material.
Please note that this course will focus on quantitative methods
column2: qualitative methods will be treated in a separate course.

column1: The goal of this course is to equip you with basic knowledge of the principles of the scientific method and the most important methodological concepts in the social and behavioral sciences. With this knowledge and hands-on practice, you will be able to evaluate research articles in terms of their methodological quality and design your own research. The course will give you insight into the current controversies surrounding the integrity of research in the social and behavioral sciences. It will also prepare you for subsequent courses on statistics and a capstone project where you will apply all this methodological and statistical knowledge and skills in performing your own research project.
• the scientific method, its principles, and criteria for evaluation
• the most important types of research and research designs
• measurement, measurement methods, and criteria for evaluation of measurement instruments
• evaluating research articles in terms of their methodological quality
• identifying solutions for methodological weaknesses found within (published) academic articles
• proposing a research design for a given research question

<body>Doel van het leeronderzoek is een eerste kennismaking met de sociaalwetenschappelijke onderzoekspraktijk, waarin&nbsp
column3: empirische cyclus doorlopen van een sociaalwetenschappelijk, hypothese toetsend onderzoek aan de hand van opdrachten . Dit onderzoek begint met een theoretisch zo goed mogelijk beredeneerd voorlopig antwoord op een relevante onderzoeksvraag waarvan vervolgens de houdbaarheid op een methodisch verantwoorde wijze empirisch wordt getoetst. In de conclusies wordt een helder antwoord gegeven op de eerder geformuleerde onderzoeksvraag en hypothesen. Afsluitend wordt gereflecteerd op de beperkingen en opbrengsten van hun onderzoek.

column1: Er wordt geoefend met twee benaderingen: een kwantitatieve, hypothese toetsende benadering en een aanvullende of verdiepende kwalitatieve benadering waarbij dataverzameling en theoretische reflectie elkaar voeden. In elk van beide benaderingen voeren studenten opdrachten uit die uiteindelijk leiden tot het doorlopen van de gehele onderzoekscyclus. De opdrachten vormen de bouwstenen van een onderzoeksverslag dat door de studenten wordt geschreven.

column2: Na afloop van het vak is de student in staat om:

column1: • een relevante en beantwoordbare centrale onderzoeksvraag te formuleren
• een studie te verrichten van relevante literatuur die helpt bij het opzetten van onderzoek en het beantwoorden van de centrale onderzoeksvraag
• een passend conceptueel model op te stellen met daarbij behorende hypothesen
• op een verantwoorde manier variabelen te operationaliseren
• een bescheiden kwantitatief onderzoek op te zetten en uit te voeren met behulp van een enquête
• een aanvullend en of verdiepend kwalitatief onderzoek op te zetten en uit te voeren met behulp van semigestructureerde interviews
• de vooropgestelde hypothesen te toetsen met een regressieanalyse van data uit de enquête en inhoudsanalyse van interviews
• de bevindingen van onderzoek systematisch en helder te rapporteren in een onderzoeksverslag
• productief te kunnen samenwerken met anderen en in een goede onderlinge verstandhouding de empirische onderzoekscylcus te doorlopen.</body>

The main objective of the Research Skills course is to help students to prepare for their Master Thesis trajectory. The course also enables students to acquire the tools needed to critically assess the significance and validity of research findings presented in academic journals, business reports, and the popular press. Students will learn the skills needed to process data, conduct an empirical analysis, interpret results, and write a research report. Students conclude the course by applying these skills to complete an empirical assignment. This course is an important step on the way to successful completion of the Master Thesis.

After having followed this course, students should know how to formulate research questions and hypotheses, how to apply econometric methods commonly used in finance to answer these research questions, and how to write and structure a thesis. Moreover, students will obtain more applied skills by learning how to collect and process financial data, how to use software for their statistical analysis, and how to present their thoughts.

This course has two major goals. First, it intends to provide students with a greater understanding in three topics in health economics which do not receive much attention in other courses of the master. Second, students will gain more in-depth knowledge by applying the econometric tools taught in the course Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics to data on each of the three topics.
The emphasis of the course is on the research angle. For each topic, a) introductory lectures will be given to set the scene
column2: b) next, students have to read papers, and solve an empirical group assignment which will consequently be discussed in class
column3: and c) finally, students have to do an individual econometric analysis based on real-life datasets.

column1: • the Becker-Murphy rational addiction model and unhealthy habits
All students that have participated in the exam/assignments of 'Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics (QMAE)' can enroll for the course, including students that failed the exam/assignments.
The exam is composed of three individual assignments. Only the final grade will be published in Osiris
Only the final grade will be published in Osiris.

<body>The major aim of this course is to acquire and apply economic and econometric tools to health issues. After this course, students should have a greater understanding of the three aforementioned topics in health economics, and have more hands-on experience with the tools acquired in the course Quantitative Methods for Applied Economics. More exactly, students should be able to:
• define the relations between ageing populations and health care expenditures
• use the Becker-Murphy rational addiction model to evaluate public health policy in the domain of unhealthy habits
• understand the important linkages between health, health insurance and the organization of the labour market, and retirement behaviour
Students should also be able to:
• combine data, economic theory and econometric tools to analyze data on one of the three topics
• present research findings on each of the 3 aforementioned topics

<body>During the research traineeship in the first year of the Research master's programme, students participate in one of the Faculty's research projects or in an external research project which is led by a Faculty member or in which a Faculty Member is involved as an advisor. The traineeship results in (a substantial contribution to) a research paper or research report and familiarizes students with some of the most vital research activities: developing a research project, writing a research proposal, doing the actual research and data analysis, and presenting research findings in the form of a research paper or research report and an oral presentation. In principle, the research subject should fit within the fields that are covered in the research master's and it should fit within the Faculty's current research projects and research interests. In order to guarantee the suitability and quality of the supervision and the traineeship, a concise research traineeship proposal should be submitted to the Programme directors who need to approve of the chosen subject and content of the traineeship before the start of the traineeship. A research traineeship includes at least the following components:
• Contribution to research report or research paper
• Attendance and active participation in presentations by fellow students.
<li>Make a substantial contribution to the development and execution of a research project (find, analyze, and synthesize state-of-the-art literature on the research subject concerned

• Give an oral presentation about the research project (research problem, aims, theoretical framework, design/methods, main findings and conclusions, stakeholders) in which they take part as a trainee
<li>Make a substantial contribution to the research paper or research report in which the main findings and conclusions of the research project are presented
• Collaborate with other researchers in a team.

column2: Bachelor Thesis course is a methodology course. The general learning objective of this course is that you acquire the skills that are necessary for critically evaluating the results of empirical studies. It is an important part of the responsibilities of a manager to draw conclusions from reports that state that “research has shown” that a variable X (an independent variable) is beneficial or detrimental for a variable Y (a dependent variable). The independent variable might be a strategy
column8: or any other variable specified in a study, and the dependent variable might be “performance”
column12: etcetera. If X really influences Y to a relevant extent, then managers are expected to use this information in their actions and decisions. The content of this course consists of the statistical and methodological principles that must be applied by a manager in evaluating the relevant evidence.

column2: Bachelor Thesis course is designed as a “practical”, consisting of a series of assignments. You learn from, first, doing something (probably for the first time and probably imperfectly) and, then, understanding and applying an instructor’s feedback on that work. You will study a course book that explains core methodological and statistical principles but you will learn what these principles mean by applying them in your own project. Your project in this course consists of writing a critical evaluation of the empirical evidence regarding a research question about the size of the influence of an independent variable on a dependent variable. You will conduct this project in a team of three students. Eventually, the Bachelor Thesis is the team’s report containing this critical evaluation.

column1: Group work At the start of the course, a description of a number of different research questions (“themes”) will be offered. Teams of three students are enrolled in one of these themes. Your success in this course will largely depend on the qualities (in terms of academic and social skills as well as in terms of personality) of your team members and the quality of the group work. Therefore it is highly recommended, before you register as a team, to spend considerable time on discussing:
Each team member’s level of ambition and potential differences between team members in this respect
Whether there are circumstances which might hinder a team member to fully participate in the team’s work
How you will organize your work.

Deadlines for submission of the assignments are strict and attendance at the feedback sessions is mandatory. Only personal and verified circumstances are legitimate reasons for absence, for insufficient participation in team work, or for not adhering to a deadline for submission of an assignment. Students who fail to comply with these requirements (e.g., students who do not sufficiently contribute to the work of their team
column2: those who submit an assignment late
column3: or do not participate in a feedback session) will not get a grade for this course (and hence fail the course) unless there are validated&nbsp
column4: reasons for failing to participate fully. The course coordinators, not the instructor, will decide on the appropriate sanctions if they cannot validate the reasons for non-attendance in a feedback session or for not meeting your other obligations in the course.</mystyle></body>

We will study selected aspects of methodology (what is research?) and empirical research methods (how do we collect and analyze data?). These topics will be applied to the students' research questions. During the course, students gradually expand the research proposal for their master thesis. Students first choose a topic and develop a possible research question, a preliminary draft of their research proposal will follow. Then they explore different ways of investigating their topic in order to decide on the most promising way forward and to improve the clarity, coherence and feasibility of their project. At the end of the course, the research proposal is assessed and successful participants move on to execute their project in Terms 3 and 4.

<body>This workshop assists students in designing a motivated and detailed research proposal for their master thesis. Successful participants will be well prepared to discuss their project with their thesis supervisor and to start conducting their own research.</body>

This course is designed to strongly support the individual thesis projects. It focuses both on the various thesis research methodologies and more practical skills to carry out the thesis project. The most important methodologies for thesis research on innovation management are qualitative case studies, surveys and archival data analyses, and experiments. The more practical issues address formal administrative procedures, managing the project with coach and co-reader, how to do a literature scan and literature review, etcetera.

The final part of this course is a one-day workshop in which an assignment is done on the research methodology meanwhile selected by the students for their thesis project. This means that students are divided into sub-groups on a specific methodology (see also thesis project).
In addition to the regular thesis objectives, this course aims at providing research skills general to all students and thesis topics in this Master Programme.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80810,2018,Research methods,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['dr. J van Dalen'],,"Inhoud
Students are required to successfully complete a prep-course by 16 September 2018.

The course presents an overview of basic quantitative research methods and techniques that are frequently used in management and provides a context for developing skills in the practical application of these methods. Quantitative methods deal with the formulation of research hypotheses, setting up causal relationships schemes, quantitative data collection, and statistical methods to perform univariate (hypothesis testing and estimation), bivariate (anova, t-test, correlation and contingency tables) and multivariate (regression) analyses. Course evaluation involves individual tests and a group assignment and group presentation in which a problem statement and research hypotheses need to be developed by the students, the process of data collection has to be conducted in real life and applied to the identified research question.

Quantitative research covers the collection and analyses of quantitative data. The lectures will address the theoretical background of measurement and analysis techniques, but also aid hands-on experience with development of surveys and application of statistical techniques to process data and support inference. The various topics are presented in four sessions: models, hypotheses and measurement theory
column4: and multivariate (regression) analysis. The distinction into univariate, bivariate and multivariate methods refers to the number of quantities involved in the analyses. Univariate methods are methods to analyze and represent the outcomes of individual variables. Bivariate methods consist of methods to analyze and represent the systematic pattern of joint outcomes of two variables, such as contingency tables, t-tests, correlation coefficients and analysis of variance. In this context, attention will be paid to phenomena, like spurious correlation, common causes and intervening variables, which can lead to highly misleading inferences if not appropriately handled. Multivariate methods are used to examine the dependencies between more than two variables at the same time. In this course, only regression analysis will be discussed. Throughout the course, attention is paid to methodological topics, such as implications of the measurement scales of available variables, the difference between statistical dependence and (assumed) causality, the possibly disturbing influence of neglected intervening variables or common causes on previously observed associations, and the difference between simple and multivariate explanatory models. The various techniques are practiced by means of computer assignments (individual exercises) aimed at acquiring practical experience with statistical techniques and the interpretation of quantitative results. Use is made of the software package SPSS for Windows, which will be covered on the fly. The last part of (almost every) lecture is dedicated to special questions and exercises for extra needs as indicated by students.

column1: This course is worth 3 ECTS (3 foundation ECTS and 2 master ECTS).</body>

<body>The objectives of this course are to have knowledge about the background and application of commonly used quantitative methods and techniques, and to have skills to apply these methods in research practice.</body>

The Research Methods in Finance course gives students the opportunity to acquire the skills needed to work with data, conduct an empirical analysis, and write an academic paper. These skills are essential for the successful completion of the Master Thesis. Students will attend lectures and workshop sessions, work on empirical assignments, and present the results of these assignments. Students can choose between two tracks: Corporate Finance or Asset Pricing. Each track consists of assignments on key topics in that field. However, the skills students train in both tracks are the same (e.g., processing data, implementing empirical methods using statistical software, and interpreting results).

Students must have a basic background in finance at the level of the core course Investments. Students are also expected to have a basic understanding of regression analysis. Students who lack this knowledge are strongly recommended to catch up prior to the start of the course by reading chapters 1 up to 5 of Brooks (2014).

<body>After having followed this course, students should know how to write and structure a thesis, be able to collect and process data, and be able to use statistical software for conducting an empirical analysis. In addition, students should understand the main econometric methods used in finance and apply these to answer research questions.</body>

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80667,2018,Research training/bachelor scriptie,Nederlands,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. R Suurmond, MSc', 'KD Bisschops']",,"Inhoud

De Research Training / Bachelor Scriptie cursus is ontworpen als een practicum, bestaande uit een reeks opdrachten. De student leert door eerst iets te doen (waarschijnlijk voor de eerste keer en waarschijnlijk imperfect) en vervolgens door de van de instructeur gekregen feedback op dat werk te begrijpen en toe te passen. De student zal een boek bestuderen dat de kern van de methodologische en statistische principes uitlegt, maar leert pas wat deze principes betekenen wanneer de student ze toepast in het eigen project. Het project van de student in dit vak bestaat uit het schrijven van een kritische evaluatie van empirisch bewijsmateriaal met betrekking tot een onderzoeksvraag over de grootte van de invloed van een onafhankelijke variabele op een afhankelijke variabele. De student dient dit project uit te voeren in een team van drie studenten. De bachelor scriptie is vervolgens het verslag van het team welke deze kritische evaluatie bevat.

<body>Het algemene leerdoel van de Research Training / Bachelor Scriptie cursus is om vaardigheden aan te leren die nodig zijn om de resultaten van empirisch onderzoek kritisch te evalueren. Meer in het bijzonder moet de student na het voltooien van deze cursus in staat zijn om:
<li>Een onderzoeksrapport te evalueren op een aantal cruciale elementen, zoals:
<li>Te vermijden dat op basis van een enkele studie door managers beslissingen worden genomen
<li>De resultaten van meerdere studies te synthetiseren
• Een kritische evaluatie te schrijven van de empirische evidentie over de omvang of de sterkte van de invloed van een onafhankelijke variabele op een afhankelijke variabele.
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/83177,2018,Researching Cultural Tourism,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,"['N van Es, MA']",,"Inhoud

Students will first be introduced in the field of cultural tourism, as an increasingly important subfield or niche of tourism in general. Cultural tourism has a long history, with roots reaching back to the Grand Tour in the 18th Century. Since then cultural tourism has been booming. Due in part to globalisation and postmodernism the character of concepts such as 'culture' and 'local identity' has become more fluid, with changing meanings to different groups in society. The ways in which tourism, visual culture and local identity are intertwining is the central theme and starting point of this research seminar. Next to that, several important qualitative research methodologies will be touched upon, familiarizing students with doing qualitative research towards cultural tourism by means of content analysis, participant observation, in-depth interviewing and ‘netnography’, amongst others. After this, students will be sent out into the field, explore how issues related to cultural tourism are acquiring significance in practice and engage hands-on in applying their methodological as well as theoretical knowledge in this field to engage with a small-scale empirical research project in line with their own interests.

Students will be made familiar with a wide range of qualitative research methods, which will prepare them for conducting an independent research towards the way(s) in which place, culture and tourism intertwine and intersect in empirical reality. In order to do so, students will practice critical analysis of sociological empirical research in the field of cultural tourism in order to learn the way research is done in practice and reported in publications. Following this, students will apply their knowledge in a small-scale qualitative research, developing a research design and acquiring hands-on experience of collecting and analysing data in addition to presenting findings amidst peers.

This course further elaborates the theoretical issues related to historical scholarship discussed in Rethinking History 1. It does so by studying key issues and currents in the philosophy of the humanities in general and in the philosophy of history (the philosophical reflection on the nature and study of history) in particular.

column19: philosophers such as Hegel and Spengler&nbsp
column26: such as positivism, hermeneutics and post-modernism raised various questions to the extent to&nbsp
column29: represent the past. What is the meaning of history and what is the nature of historical truth? How can we justify historical explanations? To what extent can we understand the intentions of historical actors? Is historical objectivity possible or even desirable? And how do historical narratives represent the past and what are the limits of historical representation?

column1: <div>Students are introduced to main concepts, theories and issues of the philosophy of history and to the main discourses and debates of Western historiography. Students are able to recognize and critically assess historiographical and philosophical issues in examples of historical scholarship. Students can take a well-argued stand in ethical and epistemological discussions&nbsp

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80202,2018,Rhetoric for managers,Engels,"Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. AJJA Maas', 'dr. JPJM Essers']",,"Inhoud

In ancient times leadership education consisted mainly in training pupils in the trivium, the three liberal arts (out of seven) dedicated to grammar, logic and rhetoric. Thus leaders, whether in politics or business, were primarily trained to become excellent communicators. Communication skills, and rhetoric specifically, were not seen or treated as a ‘bag of tricks’. They were considered essential ingredients in the character formation of the leader and the exercise of good reason. For to be a good and virtuous leader, one first of all had to become a good and virtuous person.

Today communication skills of leaders still are of crucial importance to their performance. The ability to motivate people, to maintain the reputation and public image of a company, to portray a credible organizational identity and strategic direction, to lead change or to navigate organizations through periods of crisis critically hinge on the persuasive talents of managers. Knowing your audience, framing your message creatively, and choosing the appropriate channels are decisive for effective communication. The language of management provides a plethora of examples of how issues are rhetorically framed to fit specific courses of action. Nowadays, however, as is evident in the use of social media and advertising, it is not only through words but also through the use of visual imagery that persuasive performance is determined.

This course will explore several terrains of rhetorical competence, from the classical canons of rhetoric and the use of tropes through to the latest developments in visual rhetoric. The course will take both an analytical perspective, helping students to recognize rhetorical techniques of persuasion, and provide a training ground to develop skills in compiling convincing communicative strategies and expressions.
This elective is built up around weekly lectures and accompanying workshops in which we will explore various aspects of rhetoric.
The effective use of tropes and figures of speech

Workshops will focus on several prominent ‘fields’ of rhetorical expression and competence in everyday management discourse. Which rhetorical techniques does the contemporary language of management employ to conceptualize aspects of organizational life such as: organizational identity and power, issues and risk management, change and crisis? Illustrative examples of these aspects will be elaborated to learn how to recognize the force of rhetorical moves in organizational communication. In a group assignment students will train their leadership skills by designing a rhetorically justified strategy on a relevant issue of organizational communication.
Offer students relevant insights into the structure and scope of rhetoric in managerial discourse and organizational life
Enable students to recognize and analyse aspects of rhetoric in examples of organizational communication
Explore contemporary forms of visual and multimodal rhetoric next to textual expressions of rhetoric in management practice
Provide a training ground for students to practice their leadership skills through persuasive and effective communication
After the course students are able to:
Recognize relevant elements of rhetoric in concrete examples of organizational communication
Critically evaluate practical everyday expressions of managerial discourse through their use or abuse of rhetorical techniques
Apply their acquired rhetorical skills to a relevant situation of organizational communication

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80712,2018,Risk Management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,['prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts'],,"Inhoud

The course introduces students to (financial) risk management, both from a business as well as a regulatory perspective. Students will be familiarized with techniques to measure and manage market risk, credit risk, operational risk, and liquidity risk. Students will also learn how risk models can be used in strategic decision making. The material will be illustrated with cases and a simulation.
• Understand, work with Value-at-Risk (VaR) and related risk measures for market, credit, and operational risk exposures
• Know how to hedge a book of trading exposures
• Understand how financial institutions manage a credit portfolio
• Understand the importance/impact of liquidity on financial institutions
• Understand how financial institutions optimize their value
• Be aware of recent topics in risk management

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80985,2018,Risk and Rationality,Engels,Erasmus School of Economics,,['prof.dr. PP Wakker'],,
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/80734,2018,Risk management,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['dr. H Choi', 'prof.dr. DGJ Bongaerts']",,"Inhoud

<body>This core course deals with the management of financial risk and return. This theme is discussed from the viewpoint of financial institutions, international investors and corporate firms. Various potential sources of risk are studied, including market risk, credit risk, liquidity risk and operational risk, as well as alternative approaches to measure and control risk. The course teaches you how to apply risk management in an organisation, using the concepts of hedging, insurance, risk budgeting, and risk adjusted performance measurement. Particular attention is paid to the application and valuation of derivative instruments, such as futures and options. During the course, we analyse a number of cases where risk management failed in practice.</body>
<body>After having followed this course, students should be able to
• explain why and under which conditions risk management is valuable,
• understand and calculate standard measures for market risk, such as Value-at-Risk
• hedge trading positions using standard derivatives and spot markets
• understand and use standard measures of credit risk
• understand the concept of liquidity risk and be able to correct market-risk VaR for liquidity risk
• understand the use and issues of risk management and economic capital in particular in the process of maximizing the value of a financial institution
• link recent crises to the material introduced in the course and analyze the potential benefits and problems of new regulations

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81418,2018,Risk, reputation & litigation",Nederlands,Erasmus School of Law,,"['mr. RJ de Doelder', 'mr.drs. ACW Pijls', 'prof.dr. KWH Broekhuizen', 'prof.mr. HM Vletter - van Dort']",,"Inhoud

Er wordt in Nederland steeds vaker geprocedeerd over zaken op het gebied van financieel recht. Dit vak gaat in op zowel bestuurs(straf)rechtelijke procedures (bijvoorbeeld de zaak Delta Lloyd vs. DNB) als civielrechtelijke procedures (bijvoorbeeld het Safe Haven arrest en de rente-swap zaken). Ook de groepsacties (“class actions”) van gedupeerden tegen (financiële) ondernemingen komen aan bod.

Omdat financiële ondernemingen, onder andere vanwege de kans op reputatieschade, niet negatief in de publiciteit willen komen, worden in het financieel recht veel zaken geschikt. Ook bestuursrechtelijke procedures worden als een ultimum remedium gezien. Dit vak gaat daarom niet alleen over het procederen zelf, maar ook de fasen en overwegingen die daaraan voorafgaan. Daarbij wordt ingegaan op risicobeheersing en reputatiemanagement.
Vanwege deze brede benadering hebben we ervoor gekozen niet het Nederlandse woord ‘procederen’ te gebruiken maar hebben we het vak de Engelstalige titel ‘Risk, reputation &amp
column2: litigation’ gegeven. De meeste literatuur en alle colleges zijn in het Nederlands.

column1: Aan het eind van dit vak wordt de studenten gevraagd in groepsverband een toegewezen korte juridische casus in het financieel recht voor te bereiden, op beknopte wijze juridische argumenten en tegenargumenten te presenteren of in de rol van rechter een eindoordeel te vellen.
Dit vak is uitermate geschikt voor juristen, economen en bedrijfskundigen die geïnteresseerd zijn in de juridische litigation-risico’s die financiële ondernemingen lopen.

• Inzicht in de rol en functie van bestuursrechtelijke en strafrechtelijke instrumenten in de context van het financiële toezichtrecht en de toepassing van bestuursrechtelijke dan wel strafrechtelijke handhavingsmogelijkheden.
• Kennis en begrip van risicomanagement in de financiële sector, waaronder normen met betrekking tot een beheerste en integere bedrijfsvoering.

• Inzicht in en begrip van privaatrechtelijke en publiekrechtelijke handhaving van gedragsnormen uit hoofde van financieel (toezicht)recht en de mogelijkheden om financiële ondernemingen en/of hun bestuurders aansprakelijk te stellen.
• Toepassing van zorgplichtnormen uit hoofde van de Wft respectievelijk het BW.
• Kennis van en inzicht in de handhavingsmogelijkheden van toezichthouders DNB en AFM.

• Begrip van strategische overwegingen aangaande de mogelijke reputatierisico’s in verband met juridische geschillen (daaronder begrepen ‘class actions’) en het belang van goede verhoudingen met toezichthouders en regelgevers op nationaal en internationaal niveau.

• Aanleren van vaardigheden om juridisch-litigieuze voor- en tegenargumenten te formuleren en te analyseren, (daarmee verband houdende) relevante juridische problemen in kaart te brengen en op te lossen respectievelijk daarover een juridisch relevant standpunt in te nemen.

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/82604,2018,Roots of Racism,Engels,Erasmus School of Philosophy,,['prof.dr. L van Bunge'],,Inhoud

In Europe, from the late Middle Ages onwards the concept of ‘race’ was used in order to distinguish different kinds of people. As a rule the distinctions drawn between human races were accompanied by clear cut moral hierarchies. Most early modern Europeans appear to have considered racial differences the result of a variety of external circumstances, but during the Enlightenment as a result of taxonomical attempts to classify man within the wider context of nature a modern, allegedly scientific racism arose, according to which these distinctions had a biological basis. In this course we will concentrate on the way in which European authors active prior to Darwin, who denied the reality of different human ‘species’, and to such 19th- and 20th-century racists as De Gobineau, Chamberlain, and Rosenberg tried to meet the challenge implied by the discovery of peoples and cultures that looked fundamentally different from the ones early modern Europeans had been accustomed to, born as they were into a world which only recently had started to globalize. Some of the texts involved take the superiority of the inhabitants of Europe for granted. Other early modern authors, however, reveal an evident fascination sometimes coupled with genuine admiration for indigenous ‘natives’.
Recommended literature (for mandatory literature see below):
• Abulafia, David, The Discovery of Mankind. Atlantic Encounters in the Age of Columbus (New Haven: Yale University Press, 2008).
• Allen, Theodore W., The Invention of the White Race, 2 vols. (New York: Verso, 1994-1997).
• Armitage, David, ‘John Locke, Carolina, and the Two Treatises of Government’, Political Theory 35 (2004), 602-627.
• Babbitt, Susan E., and Sue Campbell (eds.), Racism and Philosophy (Ithaca N.Y.: Cornell University Press, 1999).
• Bernal, Martin, Black Athena, The Afroasiatic Roots of Classical Civilisation, 3 vols. (New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press, 1987-2006).
• Bethencourt, Francisco, Racisms. From the Crusades to the Twentieth Century (Princeton: Princeton University Press, 2013).
• Bracken, Harry M., ‘Essence, Accident and Race’, Hermathena 116 (1973), 81-96.

• Dikötter, Frank, The Discourse of Race in Modern China (Hong Kong: Hong Kong University Press, 1992).

https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/81181,2018,Rotterdamse verhalen uit een (post)-koloniale wereld,Nederlands,Erasmus School of History, Culture and Communication",,['prof.dr. AA van Stipriaan Luiscius'],,"Inhoud

<body>In deze cursus maken studenten kennis met geschiedenis van voormalige Nederlandse koloniën en de impact daarvan op de postkoloniale samenleving, met name de Rotterdamse. Speciale aandacht zal er zijn voor de geschiedenis van Suriname, de Nederlandse Cariben en Indonesië. Dit betreft met name omstreden of vergeten stukken uit hun geschiedenis, diametraal verschillende perspectieven, de migratie van die geschiedenis en haar dragers naar Nederland en hedendaagse erfenissen van die geschiedenissen. Hoe wordt het koloniaal verleden beleefd door inwoners van Rotterdam? Wat waren de koloniale modellen van etnisch-culturele diversiteit daar &amp
column2: toen en hoe verhoudt zich dat tot postkoloniale modellen van diversiteit in het hier &amp

column1: Daarnaast is deze cursus een –voor sommigen verdere– kennismaking met het fenomeen orale geschiedenis. Dit is meer dan alleen maar een methode, het gaat ook over herinnering en over een ander soort geschiedenis. Hierin staat het individuele perspectief centraal van (de nazaten van) gekoloniseerde mensen, eventueel ook kolonisators. Het gaat meer om het verhaal, de hedendaagse beleving daarvan en de ontmoeting tussen onderzoeker en nazaat, dan om zoiets weerbarstigs als historische waarheid.

En ten slotte gaat deze cursus ook over Rotterdam en de relatie die deze stad onderhoudt met het koloniaal verleden. Studenten gaan daarvoor zelf postkoloniale Rotterdammers interviewen en daarmee nieuwe bronnen creëren.
• Studenten zijn bekend met de (post-)koloniale geschiedenis van Nederland en kunnen het verschijnsel kolonialisme en de hedendaagse impact daarvan duiden en verklaren
• Studenten kunnen de methoden van oral history toepassen en hier schriftelijk en audio-visueel verslag van doen
• Studenten kunnen een weloverwogen standpunt innemen in contemporaine debatten over culturele diversiteit en omstreden geschiedenis

The Company Based Research Project will be assessed separately from the thesis (on a pass/fail basis) by the thesis coach and a company supervisor.
THIS ELECTIVE COUNTS AS A FREE ELECTIVE FOR SCM STUDENTS ONLY. IN OTHER WORDS: in order to graduate you MUST complete at least two other SCM programme electives!
Students should use their time with the internship company to acquire skills with regard to doing SCM related research within a company setting.</body>

<li>class attendance (9 sessions, 5 sessions of 3 hrs and 4 seminars of 2 hours&nbsp
The projects will be executed in teams of three to four students, depending on the size of the project and the amount of the projects.
Most students will already be familiar with various Supply Chain Management disciplines through course work
column2: however the use of this knowledge and the capacity to translate it into practical solutions is often a new challenge. The Business Consultancy Project (BCP) permits students to combine theory and practice – they learn how to formulate a project proposal and relevant research questions, analyse problems, develop recommendations and propose solutions to the problem. In addition, BCP provides hands-on experience on how to deal with a business problem. The learning objectives of the BCP can be summarised as follows:

column1: <li>Understanding the current state of research in selected topics within Supply Chain Management, both method-wise and content-wise

<li>To learn more about management projects: to understand the work of a consultant, how to analyse supply chain problems, how to develop solutions and recommendations, and how to develop a professional client relationship
• To learn more about project management: how to run projects, how to plan and organise activities, meetings, and processes in time.

<body>The organisation of this large event is in the hands of a small committee, consisting of seven senior members of STAR. The positions within the committee are presented below:

column3: being in contact with the RSM

column1: • Treasurer: managing the budget and bookkeeping of the entire event

column2: Public Relations: creating and realising the marketing for the entire event

column1: • Commissioner of Speakers (2x): responsible for recruiting all speakers and managing relations with these speakers
• Commissioner of Commercial Relations (2x): responsible for the acquisition of the event and maintaining relations with corporate partners
• Events: responsible for the planning and organization of the event itself
Next to these positions, the modules Vice-Chairman and IT are available next to the common positions within the committee.
From all committee members it is expected that they:
• are able an willing to bear total responsibility for the project
• will be able to maintain professional relations with all stakeholders (corporates, speakers, suppliers, STAR, RSM, students)
• will be able to successfully plan and schedule the project

Essentially, functioning as a member of the committee involves ‘learning by doing’. At the same time, becoming a member is only possible when you fulfil the requirements set by STAR. Within the project, your starting qualifications will be brought to a higher level. The learning goals for the activity are such that committee members should already posses certain knowledge and skills which will be enhanced by the end of the project. The following starting qualifications and learning goals have been formulated. In brackets, courses that are part of the BSc BA or the BSc IBA have been indicated that clearly contribute to the required knowledge, skills or attitude.
Being considered for this committee, you should:

<li>be able to work in a team (Introduction to Business/Inleiding Bedrijfskunde, Organisational Behaviour/Gedrag in Organisaties, Methodology, Effective Business Communication/Bedrijfskundige Vaardigheden, Strategic Business Plan/Strategisch Ondernemingsplan
<li>have basic knowledge of how to communicate with different (international) stakeholders (Effective Business Communication
<li>have basic knowledge of bookkeeping and budgeting (Foundations of Finance &amp
column3: Management Accounting, Corporate Finance. Having completed Financial Accounting is an asset)

column1: <li>be able to rationally argue (financial) decisions to the supervisor/board (Organisational Theory &amp
• have a basic understanding of how to communicate and work together with businesses (Effective Business Communication/BKV)
<li>have a basic understanding of how to come up with a marketing plan in order to sufficiently promote the project (Marketing Management
After finishing the project, you should be able to:
• work strongly and professionally in a team
• make far-reaching decisions based on valid argumentation
• professionally conduct the bookkeeping and budgeting of encompassing projects
• professionally communicate and work together with businesses
• professionally develop, apply and evaluate the marketing of large projects
• act responsibly when dealing with large projects

<body>The STAR Management Week is the largest off-campus business and recruitment event of the Benelux and one of the highlights of the year at the Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University (RSM). During this event the students will get the opportunity to enrich their student life by participating in various activities. They will be inspired by keynote speakers during the Academic&nbsp
column2: Seminars, or by participating in discussions with well-known guests during the Honorary Discussions. The SMW also gives students the opportunity to get in contact with many companies during multiple recruitment activities. Whether students have just started their studies or are already close to graduation, during the STAR Management Week they will be offered a broad range of professional and exciting activities to participate in. The organisation of SMW is a challenging task for which only senior members of STAR are recruited who meet a range requirements, both in the field of content and in the field of skills and attitude.</body>

Adequate inrichting van de sanctionering van onwenselijk, strafbaar gedrag is al enige tijd één van de hoofdthema’s van politieke en maatschappelijke aandacht en daarom ook een kernonderdeel van het curriculum van de strafrechtelijke mastervariant. Het mastervak Sanctierecht zich op de inrichting van het strafrechtelijk sanctiestelsel in brede zin. Dit wil zeggen: het geheel van regels over, de beginselen achter en de actualiteit bij zowel de oplegging als de tenuitvoerlegging van strafrechtelijke sancties. In het kader van de tenuitvoerlegging wordt uitdrukkelijk ingegaan op vrijheidsbenemende straffen en maatregel. Er wordt niet alleen aandacht besteed aan wet- en regelgeving, maar ook aan rechtspraak en uitvoeringspraktijk. Om nader inzicht te verkrijgen in die uitvoeringspraktijk worden in het kader van dit vak praktijkexcursies georganiseerd. Ten slotte wordt in dit vak ook het Europees- en internationaalrechtelijk perspectief betrokken.

<li>het geldende sanctierecht en de bijbehorende grondslagen en systematiek van de oplegging en tenuitvoerlegging van strafrechtelijke sancties beschrijven, doorgronden, analyseren, uitleggen en beoordelen
<li>inzien hoe de wet- en regelgeving in het kader van het sanctierecht nader vorm krijgt in rechtspraak, beleid en uitvoeringspraktijk
<li>het geldende sanctierecht bezien en doorgronden in relatie tot de (uitgangspunten van) sanctionering op Europees- en internationaalrechtelijk niveau
<li>actuele juridische vraagstukken aangaande het sanctierecht doorgronden, analyseren en beoordelen in hun nationale, Europese en internationale context
• zelfstandig een kritische visie vormen op de maatschappelijke rol van het sanctierecht

Het verzekeringsrecht is verweven met de zeer diverse economische en maatschappelijke activiteiten van mens en bedrijf. Daar waar deze activiteiten een potentieel financieel risico met zich brengen, bestaat een behoefte aan verzekering. In het vak Capita Verzekeringsrecht ligt de nadruk op de consumentenverzekering. In het Kernvak Schadeverzekering staat de behoefte/noodzaak om het financieel-economische risico van de onderneming te verzekeren centraal. In dit kader zal aandacht worden gegeven aan de juridische aspecten van dergelijke verzekeringscontracten alsmede aan de bredere economische context waarin deze hun rol vervullen. Aan economische activiteiten is immers steeds het risico van aansprakelijkstelling verbonden. Als belangrijke voorbeelden van economische activiteiten gelden ten eerste grote bouwprojecten en ten tweede de handelskoop. Bij bouwprojecten zoals de aanleg van de HSL-lijn is het noodzakelijk om de zeer grote daaraan verbonden financi&euml
column3: s af te dekken met een zgn. Construction All Risks (CAR) verzekering. Hetzelfde geldt voor de economische activiteiten die samenhangen met handelskoop en het daarmee verbonden vervoer van zaken. Banken die dergelijke transacties financieren eisen doorgaans een zgn. Transportgoederenverzekering. Aard en systematiek van deze verzekeringsvorm zal aan de orde komen, evenals de bestuurdersaansprakelijkheidsverzekering. Aan de orde zal verder komen de begrenzing van de dekking op onder meer de aansprakelijkheidsverzekering voor bedrijven (AVB). Aan economische activiteiten is inherent de dreiging van een faillissement van een onderneming. Aandacht zal worden besteed aan verzekeringsrechtelijke complicaties hierbij. Tenslotte zullen aan de orde komen: het verzekerbaar belang van de onderneming, het leerstuk van risicoverzwaring, samenloop van verzekeringen, alsmede de verzekering van een rechtspersoon en de problematiek van toerekening van kennis en wetenschap binnen de onderneming bij het leerstuk van verzwijging.</body>

column1: <body>De student verwerft kennis en inzicht over de genoemde juridische onderwerpen aan de hand van bestudering van de verplicht gestelde literatuur en de collegestof. Hij/zij zal in staat zijn deze kennis en dit inzicht te tonen. Vaardigheid zal worden getoetst door van de student te vragen met toepassing van de juiste regels volgend uit de wet, jurisprudentie en literatuur, verzekeringsrechtelijke casus op te lossen, dan wel verzekeringsrechtelijke vragen te beantwoorden. Na het tonen van deze vaardigheid is de student ook in de juridische praktijk in staat een relevante bijdrage te leveren aan een juiste analyse en een mogelijke beantwoording van verzekeringsrechtelijke vraagstukken aangaande bovengenoemde onderwerpen.</body>

<body>Het erfrecht en het huwelijksvermogensrecht worden op hoofdlijnen behandeld. De student maakt voorts kennis met de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 en de Successiewet 1956. Van de Wet op belastingen van rechtsverkeer 1970 wordt alleen de overdrachtsbelasting behandeld. Bij bespreking van de overdrachtsbelasting wordt ook ingegaan op de samenloopproblematiek met de omzetbelasting en wordt tevens stil gestaan bij de cumulatie met de schenkbelasting. Bij de behandeling van de Successiewet 1956&nbsp
column2: wordt vooral ingegaan op de begrippen: 'al wat krachtens erfrecht of schenking wordt verkregen' en 'fictieve verkrijging’. Er wordt uitgebreid aandacht besteed aan de bedrijfsopvolgingsfaciliteiten. Estate Planning wordt vanuit diverse invalshoeken bezien, zowel nationaal als internationaal.

Bestuurskundigen besteden het grootste deel van hun tijd aan het op schrift stellen van hun

ideeën. Daarom is het van essentieel belang om goed te kunnen schrijven. Dit geldt ook voor afgestudeerde bestuurskundigen die niet aan een universiteit werken, maar wel vaak functies vervullen waarin een sterk beroep wordt gedaan op hun schrijfvaardigheid. De opleiding bestuurskunde hecht dan ook grote waarde aan het ontwikkelen van sterke schrijfvaardigheden. Gedurende het eerste jaar is daarom de nodige aandacht besteed aan academisch schrijven.

Gedurende deze cursus staat het “betogend schrijven” centraal. Bestuurskundigen worden immers niet alleen geacht om ‘goed’ te kunnen schrijven, maar vooral ook om in staat te zijn om naar een specifiek afgestemd publiek een boodschap te communiceren. Wetenschappers, maar ook beleidsmakers of projectmanagers moeten immers regelmatig ideeën of bevindingen overtuigend aan een breed publiek kenbaar kunnen maken. Dit vraagt van hen dat zij stelling innemen, en deze stellingname schriftelijk kunnen beargumenteren en verantwoorden. Maar dat vraagt ook om inlevingsvermogen en het kunnen aansluiten bij het referentiekader van verschillende doelgroepen. In dit vak leren studenten daarom “betogend schrijven”, met een specifieke publiek in gedachten.
• Na afloop van de cursus is de student in staat om de structuur van een betoog te herkennen
• Na afloop van de cursus is de student in staat om een overtuigend betoog te schrijven voor verschillende doelgroepen.

<body>Tijdens dit blok ga je aan de slag met het schrijven van een wetenschappelijk literatuuronderzoek. Het leren schrijven van een literatuuronderzoek is zeer nuttig, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van leeronderzoeken en scripties, daar het vertrekpunt van al het sociologische onderzoek gevormd wordt door de grondige bestudering van eerder onderzoek. Tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst wordt uitgelegd waar een goed geschreven literatuuronderzoek aan moet voldoen. De daarop volgende bijeenkomsten staan in het teken van het opzetten, schrijven en verbeteren van het literatuuronderzoek
column2: te beginnen met het opstellen van een goede probleemstelling en eindigend met het doen van aanbevelingen voor vervolgonderzoek.</body>

column1: Na afronding van deze cursus zijn studenten in staat om schriftelijk verslag te doen van een literatuuronderzoek dat de basis kan vormen voor empirisch onderzoek.</body>

<body>Tijdens dit blok ga je aan de slag met het schrijven van een onderzoeksvoorstel. Het leren schrijven van zo’n voorstel is zeer nuttig, bijvoorbeeld in het kader van de leeronderzoeken en scripties, maar ook wanneer je na je studie wetenschapper wilt worden. Dit blok staat in het teken van het indienen van een (fictief) onderzoeksvoorstel bij het NWO, één van de instellingen die in Nederland wetenschappelijk onderzoek aan universiteiten financiert. Gedurende dit practicum wordt voortgebouwd op de kennis die is opgedaan tijdens het schrijven van een literatuuronderzoek. Tijdens de eerste bijeenkomst wordt uitgelegd waar een goed voorstel aan moet voldoen. De daaropvolgende werkgroepen staan in het teken van het opzetten, schrijven en verbeteren van het voorstel
column2: te beginnen met het opstellen van een goede probleemstelling en eindigend met het maken van een planning voor je onderzoek.</body>

<body>In this course, students will be introduced to science fiction as a major genre in cinema and&nbsp
column2: literature, but also in video games, music and other media. Science fiction has the ability to invent and prevent the future, but also to provide extremely precise analyses of societies. By studying its different past representations, we will try study how science fiction contributes to the understanding of our present, but also the shaping of our future.

column1: Science fiction and media (A History of the Future) is the first course organized by CHIFT (Community for histories of the future), the platform based at Erasmus University aiming at studying and stimulating the production of science fiction in the Netherlands.
Note: The maximum number of participants is 60. This course has mandatory lectures.
• Introduction to science fiction as a media genre
• Use of science fiction to develop academic skills
• Use of science fiction to broaden media studies

column1: <font color=""black"">In dit derde blok in de Master Kinder- en Jeugdpsychologie zullen de studenten leren zich op te stellen als echte scientist practitioners. Ze zullen geconfronteerd worden met klinische en leerproblemen, waarvoor ze een wetenschappelijk gefundeerde oplossing moeten bedenken. Voorbeelden zijn: het selecteren van goed gevalideerde diagnostische instrumenten voor specifieke problematiek, het zoeken van de optimale (evidence-based) behandeling voor een kind met een bepaalde stoornis, het bekijken van evidence-based preventieprogramma&rsquo

column1: https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/86534,2018,Scientific Integrity,Engels,Rotterdam School of Management, Erasmus University",,"['prof.dr. MH van Dijke', 'prof.dr. PJF Groenen']",,"Inhoud
The course consists of three sessions, built around three key elements:

column2: what attitudes and behaviors do we expect from ERIM PhD students and members,

column1: – Codes of Conduct, such as the Erasmus University Code of Conduct, and the code of the Association of Universities in the Netherlands (VSNU)

– As part of a pre-programmed game/simulation, you experience important issues and dilemmas involved in questionable research practices. You will play the role of a PhD student who just started and runs into a number of problems and challenges, including a supervisor who is being accused of fraud. It’s your role to find out what really happened..

– In an interactive setting, you will be discussing concrete integrity dilemma’s with your fellow students, in order to understand, develop and discuss arguments for choosing a course of action when facing integrity dilemma’s.
• Assignment – enhancing a culture of scientific integrity

– You will have a choice of an individual or team assignment to conduct a brief exploration and write an essay on selected topics within the general theme of “enhancing a culture of scientific integrity”.</body>

Like in any profession, scientists are routinely faced with integrity dilemmas: Can I exclude particular observations from my research? Can I leave out certain statistics from the analysis I report? Can I use the same data set, or “idea”, in multiple papers? Can I agree on a colleague being a co-author on a paper to which (s)he has not made a significant contribution?

This course aims to expose you to such integrity dilemmas, and to support you in developing and honing your own “moral compass”. We do this partly by discussing the context of the principles, values and rules such as they apply to the field of management research in general, and to our university and research institute in particular.

As such, the course serves as a foundation for other courses, in particular the various research methodology courses and the course on Publishing Strategy, during which you will discuss in more detailed terms the various dilemma’s you will be facing in your PhD studies and possible further academic career.</body>

<body>Het schrijven van een scriptie van 12 000-16 000 woorden (10 ects) is een verplicht onderdeel van de masteropleiding Fiscaal recht. Voor de studenten van de variant Directe belastingen geldt dat het onderwerp van hun scriptie betrekking moet hebben op directe belastingen
column2: voor de studenten van de variant Indirecte belastingen zijn dat de Indirecte belastingen.

column1: Het schrijven van de masterscriptie Fiscaal recht is alleen mogelijk met deelname aan het door ons aangeboden scriptietraject. Indien u de wens heeft om in het collegejaar 2018 – 2019 af te studeren, dan dient in ieder geval uw scriptie vóór 26 juni 2018 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider. Indien de scriptie vervolgens wordt goedgekeurd door de tweede lezer, kan de scriptie worden verdedigd tijdens de afstudeerbijeenkomst van eind augustus 2019.&nbsp
Het scriptietraject bestaat uit de volgende&nbsp
<li>Goedkeuring scriptieonderwerp en aanmelding in het scriptievolgsysteem&nbsp
<li>a. Studenten variant Directe belastingen: eerste afspraak met scriptiebegeleider&nbsp
<div>b. Studenten variant Indirecte belastingen: deelname inleidende discussiebijeenkomst&nbsp

Let op: U kunt alleen aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak deelnemen als u aan de verplichte onderdelen 1 t/m 4 hebt voldaan. Dit zal voorafgaande aan het Fiscaal Confrontatievak actief worden gecontroleerd.

Het is aan te raden op tijd met de scriptie te beginnen. Uit ervaring is bekend dat vooral de eerste fase van de ontwikkeling van een scriptie (bestaande uit de keuze van het onderwerp, de literatuurverzameling en het inlezen) veel tijd kost. Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat een eventueel in het bachelorwerkstuk behandeld onderwerp niet mag worden 'uitgewerkt' tot een masterscriptie. Het onderwerp van de scriptie dient tijdig aangemeld te worden door middel van het invullen van het 'Aanmeldingsformulier scriptie (Master) Fiscaal Recht'. Na goedkeuring van het onderwerp door de sectie Fiscaal Recht ontvangt u bericht met daarin de naam van de toegewezen scriptiebegeleider. Na goedkeuring ligt het onderwerp vast.&nbsp

Met nadruk zij hier vermeld dat niet eerder aan een scriptie kan worden begonnen dan nadat het aanmeldingsformulier is ingeleverd en u bericht heeft ontvangen over het toewijzen van een scriptiebegeleider.&nbsp

Uw scriptie moet binnen twee collegejaren na aanvang van het masterscriptietraject door uw scriptiebegeleider zijn goedgekeurd. Daarna vervalt uw scriptieonderwerp. U dient dan opnieuw het gehele scriptietraject te doorlopen. Dat geldt niet voor het Fiscaal confrontatievak, indien u dat vak al met een voldoende heeft afgesloten. Indien u in het collegejaar 2018/2019 start met uw scriptie dient uw scriptie dus uiterlijk aan het eind van collegejaar 2019/2020 goedgekeurd te zijn door uw scriptiebegeleider.

In een aantal bijeenkomsten van november tot Kerst wordt een technische instructie gegeven voor het schrijven van een bachelor thesis en wordt collectief gewerkt aan het concept voor de thesis. Dat concept dient uiterlijk 1 januari, goedgekeurd door de begeleider, aan de Examencommissie te worden voorgelegd. In de bijeenkomsten tussen januari en juni, die in overleg worden geroosterd, worden in kleine groepjes tekstgedeelten van de verschillende theses in wording besproken. Deze bijeenkomsten zijn bedoeld ter ondersteuning van het schrijfproces. Voltijd studenten die in 2018-2019 hun bachelor examen willen afleggen dienen deel te nemen aan de bijeenkomsten. Zonder deelname kan geen bachelor examen worden afgelegd.

<body>Het schrijven van een concept voor de eigen bachelor thesis. Het presenteren en kritisch bespreken van tekstgedeelten uit de eigen thesis. Het constructief-kritisch becommentariëren van tekstgedeelten uit de theses van medestudenten. Het komen tot een eerste volledige versie van de thesis.</body>
https://eur.osiris-student.nl/student/osiris/owc/cursussen/85366,2018,Searching, finding and managing your literature",Nederlands,International Institute of Social Studies (ISS),,[],,"Inhoud
The session will include a mix of a short contextual presentation and some demonstrations of search techniques and databases. The main part will consist of in-class exercises based on your own topic.
After completion of the workshop you will be able to make efficient use of available sources and tools in order to create a kick start for your thesis. Specifically you will be able to:
• Locate and use search filters in databases
<li>The workshop is specifically suitable for 1st year PhD candidates, starting to orient themselves
column2: the course can also act as a refresher course.

column1: • Some experience of bibliographic database searching would be beneficial to get the most out of the workshop.
<li>Participants are not required to bring in their own data sets
column2: a first quick search into your topic is strongly advised, in order to address possible problems during the workshop.

column1: Note that this workshop has some overlap with the first course session of the PhD course ""Doing the literature"". PhD candidates who have already followed that course should consider this workshop as a refresher of that session.

• There are no preparatory assignments for this workshop, but in order to actively participate in the workshop you could have a look at the at the training and support portal of the University Library. There you can choose relevant e-modules covering the whole research cycle.
<li>You are kindly requested to create a <a href=""https://www.eur.nl/ub/en/trainingsupportportal_en/trainingsupportsearch_en/trainingsupportdetail_en/?view=showDetailed&amp
column3: open=2"" target=""_blank"" title=""Opens external link in new window"">RefWorks account before the start of the workshop.

column1: This three hour workshop focuses on practical aspects of doing your literature review. Topics include:
• How to prepare your literature search by creating a search profile
• Organizing your references: f.i. by creating a RefWorks account or Mendeley
• Choice of databases: from general / multidisciplinary (citation) databases to discipline specific sources
• Staying up-to-date via alerts on search profiles, RSS feeds or social networks like ResearchGate
• Creating your own ‘research information landscape’ by defining top authors and affiliations, top journals, and visualizing keywords with VOSviewer.
